citation.article-title: Polaribacter gen. nov., with three new species, P. irgensii sp. nov., P. franzmannii sp. nov. and P. filamentus sp. nov., gas vacuolate polar marine bacteria of the Cytophaga-Flavobacterium-Bacteroides group and reclassification of 'Flectobacillus glomeratus' as Polaribacter glomeratus comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Polaribacter filamentus sp. nov.
Polaribacter filamentus (fil.a.men'us. filamentus from L. v. filare to spin; Polaribacter filamentus a filamentous bacterium of the genus Polaribacter)
Long rods or filaments measuring 0.5-1.2 μm in width and 16-32 μm in length.
Cells are orange- to salmon-coloured and may produce gas vesicles.
This species can use L-glutamate and glycerol as carbon sources and it can hydrolyse gelatin.
It also produces acid from DL-arabinose, rhamnose, D-galactose, D-glucose, mannose and glycerol.
These cells can grow from ≤4-19°C, but not at 21°C.
Principal fatty acids include 22 % 15:0 iso-3-OH, 22% 15:0 iso and 12% 15:1 iso-G (position of double bond unknown) when grown on SWCm agar at 10°C.
Isolated from surface sea water, 350 km north of Deadhorse, Alaska.
Type strain of the species is strain 215 (= ATCC 700397).
